evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters, as alternative causes such as equipment failure or external interference have been ruled out in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to share critical information effectively during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario.

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: Statements from crew members accurately reflect their communication behavior during the event
The absence of warnings or verbal communication implies a communication breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and coordination among crew during the event
If the crew had clearly communicated and coordinated to prevent the incident

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates a lack of communication and coordination among crew members during the pushback, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not speak up when the instructor passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcripts or recordings of communications; reliance on post-event statements

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure was present and observable in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal dataset.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system failure in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal dataset would change my mind.
outcome.reasoning_summary: None of the provided history evidence items (H1-H13) mention or describe any mechanical or control failure of the aircraft or tug. The evidence focuses on human actions, communications, and procedural aspects during the pushback and collision event, with no indication of mechanical or control system malfunction.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features such as miscommunication, lack of coordination, and failure to share critical information effectively during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario.

assumptions: Assuming that the lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members indicate miscommunication and coordination breakdown
Assuming that failure to speak up or question actions reflects ineffective sharing of critical information
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If the crew had shared critical information effectively and acted on it

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows miscommunication and lack of effective coordination: the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver assumed the instructor knew what he was doing and did not speak up (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions were justified and did not question them (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of communication protocols or whether critical information was shared timely; some assumptions about crew intentions and awareness

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: Evidence showing a marking or environmental deficiency present and identifiable during the specified inspection.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or identification of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records.

assumptions: The provided history items (H1-H13) are part of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records
The historical narrative constitutes documentation and availability as per the claim
defeaters: If no formal record or report exists in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records explicitly documenting the procedural deviation
If the evidence only reflects oral history without formal documentation

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical records (H1-H13) document the procedural deviation during pushback, including the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4), notification and damage details (H6), and statements from involved personnel about the event and signals used (H8). This supports that the deviation is documented and available in the historical prefinal records.
outcome.uncertainty_source: The evidence is from historical narrative but does not explicitly state the existence of a formal documented record in the prefinal records; ambiguity whether these history items constitute the official documented record.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal data.

defeaters: If evidence showed the procedural deviation was unique or inconsistent with typical Boeing 737-8AS pushback procedures or key features in historical data
If the TRP or pushback environment was significantly different than described
If the personnel involved had different qualifications or awareness than stated

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes the pushback procedure and the deviation where the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast fence (H4), with details on the TRP location and clearance (H7). The tug instructor's method and limitations of signaling (H8), trainee and other personnel awareness of TRP (H9, H10, H12, H13) align with key features of the historical data for this Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback event.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in subjective perceptions of personnel and exact procedural norms; no explicit procedural checklist comparison provided
